categories: Rule/Concept Recall and Clarification

These sentences state established facts, formulas, definitions, or theorems from the relevant domain so the reasoner can use them as accepted premises. They bring in canonical knowledge (“In a Poisson process, the number of points…,” “The t-distribution is used instead of the z-distribution when…”), restate standard formulas (“The variance of the sum of independent variables is the sum of their variances”), or highlight core assumptions (“Fixed number of trials is required for a binomial distribution”). They do not express uncertainty or lay out plans; instead, they supply authoritative conceptual material that grounds subsequent deductions.
Equation/Fact Setup for Subsequent Calculation

These sentences translate the problem narrative into concrete quantitative or structural statements that will be used in later manipulations. Typical moves include writing or recalling a balanced reaction, specifying a mathematical expression or constant, defining symbols or initial conditions, and asserting direct stoichiometric or physical facts (e.g., “The balanced equation is …”, “Kb = [CH3COOH][OH-]/[CH3COO-]”, “For every mole of KClO₃, 3 moles of O₂ are produced”). They supply the precise intermediate data and relations needed for further computation without yet drawing final conclusions or expressing uncertainty.
Background Knowledge Recall

These sentences inject previously learned facts, definitions, formulas, constants, or legal rules into working memory so that they can later be applied in the argument. They typically appear as declarative statements—often prefaced by markers like “I remember,” “from what I recall,” “usually,” or “typically”—and supply domain‐general information rather than evaluating it or outlining next steps. Examples include defining a concept (“In probability, the geometric distribution models the number of trials needed to get the first success”), citing a rule (“Under FRE 801(d)(1)(A)…”), or recalling a physical constant (“The Sun’s effective temperature is about 5778 K”).
Intermediate Result Validation / Sanity-Check Statements

These utterances momentarily pause the chain of thought to judge whether a just-derived fact, calculation, or inference is plausible, internally consistent, or error-free. They either affirm acceptance (“That seems right,” “Yes, that’s correct”) or flag doubt/ rejection (“That can’t be right,” “That doesn’t make sense”), and often include quick comparative or magnitude checks (“That seems really large but maybe it’s okay,” “Wait, that’s the same as before”). Their purpose is to validate or invalidate intermediate steps before the reasoner proceeds further.
Domain Knowledge Recall

These sentences retrieve and state established laws, formulas, definitions, or standard conceptual relationships that are presumed true and will be used later in the derivation or calculation. They function as factual reminders—“Power is equal to force multiplied by velocity,” “The Nyquist rate is twice the highest frequency,” “The electrostatic force is given by Coulomb’s law”—supplying the canonical equations or principles that anchor subsequent problem-specific reasoning. They are typically introduced with cues like “First, I remember that…,” “I recall that…,” or “So, the formula is…,” and contain no explicit uncertainty or future-oriented action plan, just authoritative knowledge needed for the task.
Additional-Factor Enumeration

These statements deliberately broaden the scope of the analysis by flagging further angles, caveats, counter-arguments, examples, or follow-up checks that still need attention. Characteristic cues include phrases such as “I should also consider…,” “Another point is…,” “Wait, but…,” “I wonder if…,” and similar add-on language. Their role is not to propose a concrete hypothesis or admit uncertainty but to remind the reasoner to incorporate extra variables and perspectives so the eventual answer is more complete and balanced.
Problem-Fact Restatement / Data Extraction

These sentences re-articulate the concrete facts, numerical parameters, and scenario details that are already supplied in the prompt. The reasoner is essentially “copying out” or paraphrasing the givens—often prefaced by cues such as “The problem says,” “Given data,” “In this case,” or “The question is asking.” No new inference or speculation is added; the sole purpose is to place all reference information in plain view before any analysis or solution steps begin (e.g., “The pipe has a diameter of 4 inches and a surface temperature of 90 °F,” “Both are purchased at age 45,” “The null hypothesis, in this case, is that the lead level is below the allowed limit”).
Evidence-Interpretation Statements

These sentences translate a specific finding, data point, or clinical detail into its diagnostic or management implication. They explicate what a lab value, symptom, physical-exam sign, or historical fact “means,” typically using verbs such as “suggests,” “points toward,” “indicates,” “supports,” or “could be a sign of.” Their role is to connect raw observations to higher-level conclusions, thereby advancing or refining the working differential rather than merely listing facts or openly speculating without reference to evidence.
Explicit Uncertainty Acknowledgment

These statements flag the reasoner’s lack of confidence or gaps in knowledge without advancing a concrete hypothesis or plan. They employ markers like “I’m not sure,” “I’m a bit confused,” “I might be mixing things up,” or “I need to verify,” signaling that the current information is incomplete or possibly incorrect. Their function is metacognitive: they alert both writer and reader to areas that require caution, further research, or corroboration before proceeding.
Intermediate Calculation / Simplification

These sentences carry out a concrete micro-step of computation or symbolic manipulation and immediately state the resulting value or equality. They include arithmetic products and sums, unit conversions, derivative evaluations, term cancellations, modular reductions, row-operation results, enumeration counts, etc. Their sole purpose is to advance the solution by supplying an intermediate numerical or algebraic result (e.g., “The derivative of t³ is 3t²,” “72 ÷ 7 gives remainder 2,” “MgSO₄: 3.305 g/kg × 1000 = 3.305 g”) rather than to set goals, express uncertainty, or form hypotheses.
Stepwise Procedural Signposting

These sentences act as self-directed instructions that lay out the next concrete operation in a multi-step solution, thereby structuring the reasoning flow. They typically start with temporal/ordering cues such as “First,” “Next,” “Then,” “After that,” or “Finally,” and are paired with a verb of intention (“I’ll calculate…,” “I need to identify…,” “I will divide…”). The focus is on announcing or framing the upcoming action—sometimes immediately carrying it out—but always serving to orient the reasoning process and the reader to the sequence of planned computational or analytic steps.
Stepwise Plan / Problem-Decomposition Declaration

These sentences explicitly announce the next cognitive sub-task the reasoner intends to perform—such as writing down data, recalling a definition, visualizing, or “breaking the problem down.” They serve as metacognitive signposts that organize the forthcoming reasoning into an ordered sequence of manageable steps. Typical cues include “Let me…,” “First…,” “Next…,” “I need to…,” or “I’ll start by…,” followed by verbs like “break down,” “note,” “recall,” “visualize,” or “figure out.”
Background-Knowledge Recall / Formula Retrieval

These utterances explicitly pull established scientific laws, equations, definitions, or constants into working memory so they can be applied to the current problem. Typical surface cues include verbs like “remember,” “recall,” “know,” or set-up phrases such as “The formula for…,” “X is defined as…,” or “The law states….” They do not yet apply or manipulate the equation; they merely surface the relevant factual/technical knowledge (e.g., “The ideal gas law is PV = nRT,” “Turbine effectiveness is defined as…,” “I recall that ΔS = nCp ln(T₂/T₁)”).
Rule/Issue Articulation

These sentences surface the controlling legal (or domain-specific) rule and/or explicitly frame the precise issue that must be decided. They spell out doctrinal tests (“Conspiracy requires an agreement to commit a crime”), name key elements (“the force used must be proportional”), or pose the operative legal question (“the question is whether the purchaser is likely to prevail”). Typical linguistic cues include “generally,” “requires,” “the key is,” “another point is whether,” and “I need to determine.” Their function is to anchor subsequent reasoning by clarifying what legal standard applies and what factual questions matter, preparing the ground for later application and conclusion.
Background-Knowledge Recall / Context Setting

These sentences retrieve and state factual information the model already “knows” so the later reasoning has a concrete knowledge base to build on. They supply definitions, historical dates, identities, relationships, or widely accepted descriptions, often introduced by memory cues such as “I remember,” “I know,” “He mentions,” or by straightforward declaratives like “The Treaty of Versailles ended World War I.” The statements are not drawing conclusions or planning next steps; they simply lay down relevant contextual facts and concepts that subsequent analysis will rely upon.
Problem Framing and Knowledge Activation

These sentences occur at the very start of a micro-reasoning episode to orient the thinker. They either (a) restate or paraphrase the immediate task (“Okay, so I need to figure out…”) or (b) retrieve a basic fact or definition likely to be useful (“First, I know that DNAse is an enzyme that breaks down DNA”). In both cases the function is to load the relevant goal and core background knowledge into working memory, establishing the conceptual starting point before any analysis, derivation, or hypothesis testing begins.
Explicit Computational Step Execution

These sentences announce and/or perform a concrete mathematical or algorithmic operation that advances the solution (e.g., “plugging in the numbers,” “factor out t,” “compute the derivative,” “rearrange to solve for Q”). They typically start with action verbs like “compute,” “write down,” “plug in,” “solve,” “divide,” “differentiate,” or “substitute,” and immediately carry out that specific manipulation or substitution. Their sole function is to execute a localized calculation or algebraic rearrangement, not to plan broadly, hypothesize, or express uncertainty.
Prompt/Question Interpretation

These sentences pause to parse and restate what the external question actually requires—e.g., whether it asks for the “incorrect” option, the “least likely” sign, or an item “NOT” included. They frequently begin with phrases like “So, the question is asking…,” “Wait, but the question is about…,” or “I need to figure out what it’s asking,” and often note missing answer choices or clarify task parameters. The cognitive role is to ensure the reasoner fully understands the task constraints before generating or evaluating substantive content.
Conceptual Clarification / Integrative Summary

These sentences crystallize the reasoning up to that point by restating, defining, or synthesizing the key idea the model has just worked through. They often begin with cues like “So,” “In summary,” “Putting it all together,” or embed definitional phrases (“means that,” “is about”) and modal hedges (“might,” “likely”) to convey a tentative but integrative conclusion. Their role is to consolidate scattered observations or arguments into a single, clearer takeaway before the chain of thought proceeds.
Issue-Spotting / Sub-Issue Framing

These sentences mark and isolate the specific questions, facts, or legal doctrines that must be resolved next.  They highlight what “the key” or “another point” is, restate salient facts, or propose alternative angles (“Alternatively…”, “So, if…”) in order to carve the overall problem into manageable sub-issues for later analysis.  They are mid-stream analytic pivots—flagging where attention should go—rather than final conclusions, stepwise plans, or mere expressions of uncertainty.
Intermediate Quantitative Computation & Formula Definition

These sentences advance the reasoning by executing concrete mathematical operations or by formally setting up the equations needed for later steps. They include (a) explicit arithmetic or algebraic calculations with the resulting numeric value stated (“So, $7,000 – $750 = $6,250”; “So, the expected return is e^{0.10} ≈ 1.10517”) and (b) the declaration or labeling of symbols and formulas that will be used in subsequent computations (“\(P\) is the principal loan amount”; “The formula for the intrinsic value is D / (r – g)”). Their cognitive role is to translate earlier qualitative or contextual information into precise quantitative terms that can be directly manipulated in the solution process.
Explicit Mathematical Computation / Equation-Manipulation Steps

These sentences carry out the mechanical work of a quantitative argument: they state a formula, substitute numbers or symbols, rearrange terms, differentiate or integrate, equate two expressions, or report the immediate numeric/algebraic result of such operations. They do not speculate, plan, or reflect on uncertainty; instead, they execute a concrete calculation or symbolic transformation that advances the solution one deterministic step (e.g., “Real GDP = (Nominal GDP / GDP deflator)”, “∂u/∂y = 2ay + 1”, “ΔP = (8μ/(πr⁴)) (Q/πr²) L”).
Tentative Background Knowledge Recall

These sentences surface domain facts or conceptual linkages that the reasoner believes might be relevant, typically introduced with hedging cues (“I think,” “maybe,” “if I recall correctly,” “I remember”) or light summarizers (“so,” “in summary”).  Their function is to retrieve and lay out factual material from memory as raw ingredients for later inference, not to outline a plan, voice pure uncertainty, or propose a testable hypothesis.  Examples include statements like “The medulla produces hormones like adrenaline,” “IP is essential for routing data across the internet,” or “I think the tip of the tongue drains into the submandibular nodes.”
Unit-Conversion & Dimensional-Consistency Check

These sentences explicitly ensure that every numerical quantity is expressed in compatible units before a calculation proceeds. They introduce or perform conversions (“I need to convert that to kg/m³,” “1 slug is 32.174 lb”), recall constant values with their units, or pause to verify dimensional coherence (“Let me see if the units make sense,” “But wait, temperature needs to be in Kelvin”). The core function is guarding against dimensional errors by aligning all terms in a common, appropriate unit system.
Stating Intermediate Results (Working-Out)

These sentences assert concrete outcomes—numbers, simplified equations, logical relations, or short factual conclusions—that have just been obtained from a preceding calculation or deduction. They document the “work in progress,” turning a prior operation into an explicit piece of information that the next reasoning step can use. Typical cues are connective adverbs like “so,” “then,” “therefore,” “now,” followed by an equality, inequality, ratio, identified category, or Boolean verdict (e.g., “y = 0.01,” “cos θ = 1,” “Thus the subgroup has 6 divisors,” “Both parts T. Argument is T.”).
Illustrative Elaboration / Example-Giving

These sentences expand on a claim that has already been raised by supplying concrete examples, plausible consequences, or specific manifestations (“for example…,” “this could lead to…,” “they might…”). The speaker is not staking out a new hypothesis or admitting uncertainty; rather, they are fleshing out the idea just mentioned so the reader can picture how it plays out in real life. Typical cues include “for instance,” “like,” “such as,” “this might mean that…,” followed by a scenario, consequence, or illustrative detail.
Self-Monitoring / Error-Checking Interjections

These sentences act as metacognitive “debug” flags: the reasoner pauses to question, verify, or correct a just-made statement or calculation. They are typically brief, conversational interjections introduced by cues like “Wait,” “Hold on,” “But,” or “Hmm,” and are followed by a negation or query (“that’s not right,” “is that correct?”). Rather than adding new content, they mark the detection of a possible mistake or ambiguity and trigger an immediate internal review before proceeding.
Concept/Principle Assertion

These utterances present domain knowledge or straightforward cause-and-effect links that the rest of the reasoning will rely on.  They state definitions (“Fractional reserve banking is …”), summarize established models (“The firm maximizes profit by setting MR = MC”), or draw direct logical implications from prior premises (“So, total revenue decreased,” “If demand rises, the price level must adjust upward”).  They function as declarative premises—laying out the factual or theoretical groundwork—rather than expressing doubt, forming hypotheses, or outlining future steps.
Self-Verification / Double-Check Cue

These sentences signal a metacognitive pause in which the reasoner intends to re-examine, recalculate, or otherwise verify work already done before proceeding. They typically contain verbs like “double-check,” “verify,” “check,” “recalculate,” “think again,” or phrases such as “let me make sure,” “let me recall,” and “maybe I should look up…,” indicating an explicit quality-control step aimed at catching possible errors or omissions.
Explicit Intermediate Calculation

These sentences function as on-the-spot “scratch-pad” arithmetic: the reasoner actually performs a specific numeric or algebraic operation and states the resulting intermediate value before moving on. Typical forms include visible calculations (“240 V × 4 A = 960 W”), conversions (“500 g is 0.5 kg”), approximations (“√5.555 ×10⁻⁴ ≈ 0.0236”), or simplifications of formulas. They supply concrete numeric results instead of plans, hypotheses, or expressions of uncertainty, acting as the computational glue that links successive steps in quantitative reasoning.

0.title: Rule/Concept Recall and Clarification
0.description: These sentences state established facts, formulas, definitions, or theorems from the relevant domain so the reasoner can use them as accepted premises. They bring in canonical knowledge (“In a Poisson process, the number of points…,” “The t-distribution is used instead of the z-distribution when…”), restate standard formulas (“The variance of the sum of independent variables is the sum of their variances”), or highlight core assumptions (“Fixed number of trials is required for a binomial distribution”). They do not express uncertainty or lay out plans; instead, they supply authoritative conceptual material that grounds subsequent deductions.
examples: Another point is that the residuals can be used to form a test statistic for hypothesis testing, especially when we're checking if a variable has a significant impact on the dependent variable
Another point is that the confidence interval for the intercept is often wider than that for the slope because the intercept is estimated without any predictors, so it has more variability

Also, I think that the SRF is always a consistent estimator of PRF under certain regularity conditions, like the population regression function is differentiable and the expected value of the square of the errors is finite
This is important because if residuals are uncorrelated, we can rely on certain statistical tests, like t-tests for individual coefficients, because the standard errors are calculated correctly
In simple linear regression, the SRF is indeed an unbiased estimator of the PRF if the population regression function exists and the sample is drawn from that population
Another point is that the PRF can be estimated using the SRF, and the SRF provides an estimate of the slope and intercept of the PRF
Another point is that the regression coefficients in the sample are estimates of the population coefficients

But wait, when μ = 65, the test statistic Z is calculated as (x̄ - μ0)/σ * sqrt(1/n), where x̄ is the sample mean, μ0 is the null mean, σ is the population standard deviation, and n is the sample size
Alternatively, if a statement says that the sample intercept is an unbiased estimator of the population intercept, that's true because under certain conditions, the sample estimates are unbiased
In OLS, when there's autocorrelation, the standard errors are typically underestimated because the model doesn't account for it
Hypothesis tests in OLS rely on the standard errors, which are based on the assumption of no autocorrelation
So, when we're estimating the population mean, we can use the t-distribution with n-1 degrees of freedom instead of the z-distribution with infinite degrees of freedom
So, the distribution of \( \bar{X} - \bar{Y} \) is normal with a mean equal to \( \mu_X - \mu_Y \) and a standard deviation that is the square root of the sum of the variances of the two populations
If the residuals follow a normal distribution, it's called homoscedasticity, and this is a good thing because it allows us to rely on the standard errors and confidence intervals

The formula for the standard error (se) in simple linear regression is sqrt[(s² / n) * (1 / Var(x))], where s² is the residual variance and Var(x) is the variance of the independent variable x. So, if residual variance s² increases, se increases

1.title: Equation/Fact Setup for Subsequent Calculation
1.description: These sentences translate the problem narrative into concrete quantitative or structural statements that will be used in later manipulations. Typical moves include writing or recalling a balanced reaction, specifying a mathematical expression or constant, defining symbols or initial conditions, and asserting direct stoichiometric or physical facts (e.g., “The balanced equation is …”, “Kb = [CH3COOH][OH-]/[CH3COO-]”, “For every mole of KClO₃, 3 moles of O₂ are produced”). They supply the precise intermediate data and relations needed for further computation without yet drawing final conclusions or expressing uncertainty.

Let me denote the initial pressure of N₂O₄ as P. Since the reaction is N₂O₄ ⇌ 2 NO₂, the stoichiometry tells me that for every mole of N₂O₄ that dissociates, I get 2 moles of NO₂

Now, looking at the balanced equation, 2 moles of KClO3 produce 3 moles of O2

Since the reaction is SO₂Cl₂ ⇌ SO₂ + Cl₂, I can express the concentrations (or partial pressures) at equilibrium in terms of α. Let me denote the initial concentration of SO₂Cl₂ as C. Then, at equilibrium:
Now, looking at the balanced chemical equation, I see that 3 moles of Cl2 are produced for every mole of KClO3
So, from this reaction, 2 moles of sodium react with 2 moles of water to produce 2 moles of sodium hydroxide and 1 mole of hydrogen gas
The formation of 2 moles of H₂O from the elements in their standard states (H₂ gas and O₂ gas) is the reverse of the cell reaction

Now, since BrCl is a product, and the reaction is Br2 + Cl2 ⇌ 2BrCl, the initial concentration of BrCl is 0.00573 M, and initially, Br2 and Cl2 are at their standard states, which I assume is zero concentration because they are reactants and not initially present
Since the reaction is I2 ⇌ 2I, for every 1 mole of I2 that reacts, 2 moles of I are produced
Let me write down the balanced equation again: Cl₂(g) + (7/2)O₂(g) → Cl₂O₇(g)

2.title: Background Knowledge Recall
2.description: These sentences inject previously learned facts, definitions, formulas, constants, or legal rules into working memory so that they can later be applied in the argument. They typically appear as declarative statements—often prefaced by markers like “I remember,” “from what I recall,” “usually,” or “typically”—and supply domain‐general information rather than evaluating it or outlining next steps. Examples include defining a concept (“In probability, the geometric distribution models the number of trials needed to get the first success”), citing a rule (“Under FRE 801(d)(1)(A)…”), or recalling a physical constant (“The Sun’s effective temperature is about 5778 K”).

3.title: Intermediate Result Validation / Sanity-Check Statements
3.description: These utterances momentarily pause the chain of thought to judge whether a just-derived fact, calculation, or inference is plausible, internally consistent, or error-free. They either affirm acceptance (“That seems right,” “Yes, that’s correct”) or flag doubt/ rejection (“That can’t be right,” “That doesn’t make sense”), and often include quick comparative or magnitude checks (“That seems really large but maybe it’s okay,” “Wait, that’s the same as before”). Their purpose is to validate or invalidate intermediate steps before the reasoner proceeds further.
examples: That seems right
Yeah, that seems right
Yeah, that seems right
Yeah, that seems right
Yeah, that seems right
Yeah, that seems right
Yep, that seems right
Yeah, that seems right
Yeah, that seems correct
That seems right
Yeah, that seems right
Yeah, that seems right
Yeah, that seems right
Yeah, that seems right
Yeah, that seems right

4.title: Domain Knowledge Recall
4.description: These sentences retrieve and state established laws, formulas, definitions, or standard conceptual relationships that are presumed true and will be used later in the derivation or calculation. They function as factual reminders—“Power is equal to force multiplied by velocity,” “The Nyquist rate is twice the highest frequency,” “The electrostatic force is given by Coulomb’s law”—supplying the canonical equations or principles that anchor subsequent problem-specific reasoning. They are typically introduced with cues like “First, I remember that…,” “I recall that…,” or “So, the formula is…,” and contain no explicit uncertainty or future-oriented action plan, just authoritative knowledge needed for the task.
examples: So, if the rope is being pulled at a certain speed, the tension in the rope must provide both the force to lift the load and the force to accelerate it
If the rope is being pulled at speed v, the force needed is the force due to the weight plus the force due to the acceleration

So, the total force on the ball is the pitcher's force plus the gravitational force

The total weight of the chain is W = m g l. The applied force P is acting at the end of the chain, so the tension throughout the chain must be equal to P divided by the length l, because the force is applied at one end

5.title: Additional-Factor Enumeration
5.description: These statements deliberately broaden the scope of the analysis by flagging further angles, caveats, counter-arguments, examples, or follow-up checks that still need attention. Characteristic cues include phrases such as “I should also consider…,” “Another point is…,” “Wait, but…,” “I wonder if…,” and similar add-on language. Their role is not to propose a concrete hypothesis or admit uncertainty but to remind the reasoner to incorporate extra variables and perspectives so the eventual answer is more complete and balanced.
examples: I should also think about examples
I should also think about examples

6.title: Problem-Fact Restatement / Data Extraction
6.description: These sentences re-articulate the concrete facts, numerical parameters, and scenario details that are already supplied in the prompt. The reasoner is essentially “copying out” or paraphrasing the givens—often prefaced by cues such as “The problem says,” “Given data,” “In this case,” or “The question is asking.” No new inference or speculation is added; the sole purpose is to place all reference information in plain view before any analysis or solution steps begin (e.g., “The pipe has a diameter of 4 inches and a surface temperature of 90 °F,” “Both are purchased at age 45,” “The null hypothesis, in this case, is that the lead level is below the allowed limit”).

7.title: Evidence-Interpretation Statements
7.description: These sentences translate a specific finding, data point, or clinical detail into its diagnostic or management implication. They explicate what a lab value, symptom, physical-exam sign, or historical fact “means,” typically using verbs such as “suggests,” “points toward,” “indicates,” “supports,” or “could be a sign of.” Their role is to connect raw observations to higher-level conclusions, thereby advancing or refining the working differential rather than merely listing facts or openly speculating without reference to evidence.

8.title: Explicit Uncertainty Acknowledgment
8.description: These statements flag the reasoner’s lack of confidence or gaps in knowledge without advancing a concrete hypothesis or plan. They employ markers like “I’m not sure,” “I’m a bit confused,” “I might be mixing things up,” or “I need to verify,” signaling that the current information is incomplete or possibly incorrect. Their function is metacognitive: they alert both writer and reader to areas that require caution, further research, or corroboration before proceeding.

9.title: Intermediate Calculation / Simplification
9.description: These sentences carry out a concrete micro-step of computation or symbolic manipulation and immediately state the resulting value or equality. They include arithmetic products and sums, unit conversions, derivative evaluations, term cancellations, modular reductions, row-operation results, enumeration counts, etc. Their sole purpose is to advance the solution by supplying an intermediate numerical or algebraic result (e.g., “The derivative of t³ is 3t²,” “72 ÷ 7 gives remainder 2,” “MgSO₄: 3.305 g/kg × 1000 = 3.305 g”) rather than to set goals, express uncertainty, or form hypotheses.

24.title: Stating Intermediate Results (Working-Out)
24.description: These sentences assert concrete outcomes—numbers, simplified equations, logical relations, or short factual conclusions—that have just been obtained from a preceding calculation or deduction. They document the “work in progress,” turning a prior operation into an explicit piece of information that the next reasoning step can use. Typical cues are connective adverbs like “so,” “then,” “therefore,” “now,” followed by an equality, inequality, ratio, identified category, or Boolean verdict (e.g., “y = 0.01,” “cos θ = 1,” “Thus the subgroup has 6 divisors,” “Both parts T. Argument is T.”).

25.title: Illustrative Elaboration / Example-Giving
25.description: These sentences expand on a claim that has already been raised by supplying concrete examples, plausible consequences, or specific manifestations (“for example…,” “this could lead to…,” “they might…”). The speaker is not staking out a new hypothesis or admitting uncertainty; rather, they are fleshing out the idea just mentioned so the reader can picture how it plays out in real life. Typical cues include “for instance,” “like,” “such as,” “this might mean that…,” followed by a scenario, consequence, or illustrative detail.

26.title: Self-Monitoring / Error-Checking Interjections
26.description: These sentences act as metacognitive “debug” flags: the reasoner pauses to question, verify, or correct a just-made statement or calculation. They are typically brief, conversational interjections introduced by cues like “Wait,” “Hold on,” “But,” or “Hmm,” and are followed by a negation or query (“that’s not right,” “is that correct?”). Rather than adding new content, they mark the detection of a possible mistake or ambiguity and trigger an immediate internal review before proceeding.

27.title: Concept/Principle Assertion
27.description: These utterances present domain knowledge or straightforward cause-and-effect links that the rest of the reasoning will rely on.  They state definitions (“Fractional reserve banking is …”), summarize established models (“The firm maximizes profit by setting MR = MC”), or draw direct logical implications from prior premises (“So, total revenue decreased,” “If demand rises, the price level must adjust upward”).  They function as declarative premises—laying out the factual or theoretical groundwork—rather than expressing doubt, forming hypotheses, or outlining future steps.
examples: In the short run, if aggregate demand increases, the price level decreases because businesses produce more, but if aggregate supply also increases, that might affect the price level differently

Aggregate demand is the demand for goods and services, so if prices are rising, people buy less, which is a leftward shift

28.title: Self-Verification / Double-Check Cue
28.description: These sentences signal a metacognitive pause in which the reasoner intends to re-examine, recalculate, or otherwise verify work already done before proceeding. They typically contain verbs like “double-check,” “verify,” “check,” “recalculate,” “think again,” or phrases such as “let me make sure,” “let me recall,” and “maybe I should look up…,” indicating an explicit quality-control step aimed at catching possible errors or omissions.

29.title: Explicit Intermediate Calculation
29.description: These sentences function as on-the-spot “scratch-pad” arithmetic: the reasoner actually performs a specific numeric or algebraic operation and states the resulting intermediate value before moving on. Typical forms include visible calculations (“240 V × 4 A = 960 W”), conversions (“500 g is 0.5 kg”), approximations (“√5.555 ×10⁻⁴ ≈ 0.0236”), or simplifications of formulas. They supply concrete numeric results instead of plans, hypotheses, or expressions of uncertainty, acting as the computational glue that links successive steps in quantitative reasoning.
examples: 4.33 × 1.602 = let's see, 4 × 1.602 is 6.408, and 0.33 × 1.602 is approximately 0.529, so total is about 6.937
First, 1351 * 9.78 = let's see, 1351 * 10 is 13510, subtract 1351 * 0.22, which is approximately 1351 * 0.2 = 270.2 and 1351 * 0.02 = 27.02, so total subtraction is 270.2 + 27.02 = 297.22

8.314 * 1223.15 ≈ Let's see, 8 * 1223 is about 9778, and 0.314 * 1223 ≈ 383, so total is approximately 9778 + 383 = 10161 J/(mol)

categories: Problem-Given Restatement / Fact Extraction

These sentences simply pull information straight from the prompt—repeating the question, listing numerical values, naming variables, or rephrasing what must be found. They function to get all the “givens” onto the workspace before any real analysis begins. Typical cues include phrases like “The problem says…,” “The question is asking…,” “First, the problem gives…,” or “The goal is…,” followed by verbatim data or task statements rather than interpretation or calculation.
Intermediate Deductive Inference

These sentences articulate conclusions or quantitative relationships that follow directly from earlier premises, definitions, or standard formulas. They do not merely cite uncertainty or outline a plan; instead, they carry the reasoning forward by applying known laws (“since F = ma…”, “λ = v/f so the wavelength changes”) or by syllogistic logic (“so the lever arm is zero”, “therefore power is inversely proportional to n − 1”). Functionally, they serve as stepping-stone results—explicitly stating what has just been deduced so that later steps can build on these established intermediate facts.
Explicit Uncertainty & Tentative Estimation

These sentences openly signal that the reasoner lacks precise knowledge, is recalling information only approximately, or must consult outside sources before firming up a claim. Typical linguistic markers include “I’m not sure,” “maybe,” “I think,” “I recall,” “it might be,” and “I should check.” The function is to flag epistemic limits, supply rough provisional numbers or impressions, and prompt follow-up verification rather than to advance a definite hypothesis or conclusion.
Rule/Criteria Recall

These utterances retrieve and articulate established doctrinal rules, statutory elements, or standard tests that must be applied to the facts. The speaker is essentially “quoting from the rulebook,” listing the definitional ingredients of crimes, torts, or defenses (“Negligence requires duty, breach, causation, and damages,” “Voluntary manslaughter involves heat of passion,” “For self-defense the defendant must reasonably fear imminent harm”). They convey settled knowledge rather than speculation, uncertainty, or procedural planning, and serve to anchor later analysis in the correct governing standards.
Alternative-Hypothesis Generation (Differential Building)

These utterances introduce or weigh possible explanations, diagnoses, or interventions that might account for the data at hand. Characterised by modals and hedging phrases (“could be,” “might,” “maybe,” “alternatively,” “I should also consider”), they list or compare candidate conditions, mechanisms, or next steps, often adding quick evidence for or against each. Their cognitive role is to expand the search space by constructing a differential set of competing hypotheses that later reasoning will confirm, refine, or discard.
Question Parsing & Option-Filtering

These sentences explicitly analyze the exam-style prompt itself—restating what the question asks, recalling or hypothesizing the given choices, and articulating the rule for picking the correct (or incorrect/exception) option. The reasoner is not yet supplying domain facts but setting the decision frame: “the question is asking which…,” “the options are…,” “I need to decide which statement is false,” “if one option says…, that would be wrong.” By clarifying scope, surfacing missing choices, and announcing provisional eliminations, they narrow the candidate answers before substantive justification begins.
Intermediate Causal-Inference / Mechanism Elaboration

These sentences take a fact, formula, or premise that has just been stated and immediately work out what follows from it, laying out the causal or quantitative implications that move the argument forward. Marked by cue words such as “so,” “that means,” “if … then,” “therefore,” or modal verbs (“would,” “could,” “might”), they apply domain rules to derive an intermediate result, explain a mechanism, or predict a downstream effect (e.g., “so the bank can lend more,” “higher interest rates reduce investment,” “this could worsen the trade deficit”). The function is to stitch facts into a logical chain that bridges raw data and the eventual conclusion.
Contextual Knowledge Recall & Elaboration

These sentences inject remembered or generally‐known facts, descriptions, or illustrative examples into the discussion so the reasoner has raw material to work with. Typically framed in a first-person or hedged style (“I remember…,” “I think…,” “Maybe…,” “Alternatively…”), they restate background history, definitions, timelines, or comparative details without yet committing to a conclusion or outlining a next step. Their function is to stock the workspace with potentially relevant information that subsequent reasoning can test, refine, or discard.
Intermediate Quantitative Calculation

These sentences perform the concrete mathematics inside the broader argument. They set up formulas, define or label variables, plug specific numbers into those formulas, carry out arithmetic, and state the resulting interim figures. Typical signals include verbs like “calculate,” “compute,” “determine,” or phrases such as “so the present value is…,” “where r is…,” “plugging in the numbers,” or “therefore the amount equals….” They supply the numerical scaffolding that later reasoning steps will reference or build upon.
Explicit Intermediate Calculation

These sentences carry out and state the results of low-level arithmetic or algebraic operations—multiplications, divisions, exponentiation, unit conversions, rounding, or quick magnitude checks—that advance the solution of a larger quantitative problem. They neither introduce new hypotheses nor reflect on uncertainty; their sole purpose is to convert given numbers or symbolic expressions into the next numeric value needed for the overall argument. Typical cues include verbs like “so,” “then,” “first,” or “let me compute,” followed by concrete numeric manipulation and an immediate stated result or approximation.
Unit-Conversion & Dimensional-Consistency Check

These sentences focus on making sure every numerical quantity carries compatible units before further calculation. The speaker converts values between measurement systems, recalls constant values in specific units, multiplies or divides to cancel dimensions, and flags mismatches (“that doesn’t seem right”). Typical cues include verbs like “convert,” “check,” “use,” or “need to make sure,” explicit unit symbols (J, kg, ft, atm, eV, etc.), and algebraic comparisons of resulting dimensions.
Factor Enumeration / Perspective Expansion

These statements deliberately broaden the scope of inquiry by listing further variables, angles, examples, exceptions, or contextual details that might matter. They function as self-reminders to keep the reasoning comprehensive rather than drawing conclusions, often introduced with phrases like “I should also consider…,” “Another point is…,” “Another angle…,” or “I also wonder….”
Integrative Summary / Synthesis Statement

These sentences appear after a stretch of reasoning to gather the previously discussed facts, analyses, or sub-conclusions into a concise recap or final answer. They use cue phrases such as “Putting it all together,” “In summary,” “So, to sum up,” “Therefore,” or “I think I’ve covered the main points,” and their primary role is to synthesize disparate elements into a unified takeaway or conclusion rather than to introduce new information, speculate, or outline future steps.
Intermediate Derivation / Computation Reporting

These sentences state the immediate outcome of a just-performed algebraic, numeric, or logical operation, locking in a partial result before the reasoning proceeds. They present definitive conclusions of sub-calculations (“So, w = 0”, “det(A) = 1”, “15*10x = 150x”), give simplified expressions or evaluated probabilities, or note a corrected derivation (“Wait, no, each double bond has one sigma and one pi”). Typically introduced by cues like “so,” “that means,” “which gives,” they neither propose new hypotheses nor lay out future steps but simply record the concrete result of a computation or local inference.
Explicit Uncertainty Acknowledgment

These utterances serve a metacognitive role: the reasoner overtly flags doubt, gaps in knowledge, or possible mistakes in the ongoing line of thought. They do not advance a new hypothesis or plan; instead they mark the current claim or recollection as tentative and signal that verification or clarification is still needed. Typical linguistic cues include “I’m not sure…,” “I might be mixing this up…,” “I’m a bit confused…,” “I don’t think that’s right,” or “I’m not 100 % certain.”
Concrete Equation Instantiation

These sentences perform the mechanical, execution-level step of reasoning where a general formula is written down, rearranged, and/or supplied with specific symbol values to yield an intermediate algebraic or numeric result. They typically appear as standalone equations or very terse prose surrounding an equation (e.g., “So, V₂ = V₁ · T₂/T₁” or “ΔS = 826.0 Btu/lbm ÷ 400 °F = 2.065 Btu/(lbm·°F)”). Their purpose is neither to plan, hypothesize, nor express uncertainty but to carry out the concrete calculation that advances the solution one quantitative step.
Domain-Knowledge Recall / Formula Invocation

These sentences explicitly retrieve and state general laws, equations, definitions, or standard relationships from the relevant discipline so the solver can apply them to the specific problem at hand. Typical cues are phrases like “the formula for…,” “I remember that…,” “let me recall…,” or direct name-dropping of principles (Ideal Gas Law, Newton’s Law of Cooling, Arrhenius equation, etc.). Their role is to surface authoritative background knowledge, not to speculate, plan, or acknowledge uncertainty.
Fact Restatement / Premise Recall

These sentences simply bring specific facts of the scenario into working memory so the model can later analyze them.  They recount who did what, when, where, or raise a narrowly framed factual question, without yet evaluating, hypothesizing, or planning.  Typical forms are short declarative or clarifying questions that paraphrase the prompt (“The package broke open and a white powder spilled out”; “If someone is in immediate danger, does the therapist have to break confidentiality?”).  Their sole function is to list or highlight raw premises that subsequent reasoning will rely on.
Local Computation / Intermediate Derivation

These sentences execute a single, concrete mathematical or logical operation and immediately state the resulting intermediate fact needed for the next step of the solution. Typical actions include introducing a substitution (“Let u = x – 1.5”), recalling a formula (“The derivative of ln x is 1/x, so g′(x)=10/x”), performing a quick calculation (“bd = 1, so b and d must be ±1”), or drawing a short deductive consequence (“Since A₃ has order 3, S₃/A₃ has order 2”). They are not merely plans or conjectures; they actually carry out part of the derivation, recording the micro-results that build toward the final answer.
Principle Recall & Conceptual Explanation

These utterances retrieve, state, or clarify established statistical or mathematical rules, definitions, formulas, and assumptions so that they can be applied in the current problem. They function as knowledge look-ups: “Let me recall that the z-score is (X – μ)/σ,” “Since Chebyshev’s inequality gives an upper bound…,” “The null hypothesis is H₀: p₁ = p₂,” etc. Rather than proposing new hypotheses or outlining next steps, they explain or restate canonical principles, ensuring the solver (and reader) has the necessary theoretical footing before proceeding with calculations or decisions.
Background Knowledge Recall

These sentences retrieve and state factual information, standard definitions, canonical formulas, or well-known examples from long-term memory so the solver can employ them later in the chain of reasoning. Typical cues include phrases like “I remember that…,” “I think…,” explicit constants, equations, or textbook facts, all delivered without immediate inference or evaluation. Their primary role is to supply the raw informational building blocks—laws, definitions, data, and illustrative cases—that subsequent analytical steps will reference or manipulate.
Conditional Counter-Argument Generation

These sentences introduce and weigh alternative legal possibilities—often framed with “if,” “but,” “another point,” or modals such as “might,” “could,” and “maybe.”  The reasoner uses them to surface potential objections, exceptions, or outcomes (“If the buyer can show… the judgment could be reversed,” “But the state is arguing…,” “Another point is the public’s right to know”), thereby stress-testing the current position and mapping the consequences of different factual or doctrinal contingencies.
Metacognitive Self-Directive / Immediate Task Cue

These sentences are the reasoner’s on-the-fly instructions to themself, signalling an immediate micro-action—compute a value, re-check algebra, recall a definition, write down an equation, consult a reference, etc. They function as metacognitive cues that shift attention to a concrete sub-task for verification, clarification, or computation, usually framed with verbs like “let me,” “wait,” or “maybe I should.” Unlike broad stepwise plans, they announce and execute a single, localized operation right away, helping the thinker maintain accuracy and momentum through continual self-checking and incremental progress.
Forward Rule-Based Deduction

These sentences apply already-accepted domain rules or definitions to the specific facts at hand and state the immediate, deterministic consequences. Triggered by cues like “so,” “therefore,” or “if … then,” they translate general principles (e.g., Mendelian ratios, Hardy-Weinberg math, chromosomal behavior) into concrete interim results such as genotype assignments, allele frequencies, or probability values. They do not speculate, express doubt, or outline future steps; instead, they deliver logical sub-conclusions that move the reasoning chain forward.
Concrete Calculation / Manipulation Step

These utterances mark the immediate execution of a specific mathematical or algebraic operation—substituting known values, rearranging an equation, expanding a product, taking a derivative, computing a numerical result, etc. They usually begin with cues like “now,” “so,” or “let me,” paired with action verbs such as “compute,” “plug in,” “solve,” “expand,” or “simplify,” and they proceed to carry out that single, explicit manipulation needed to move the solution forward.
Problem Restatement / Task Framing

These sentences occur at (or near) the outset of the reasoning trace and serve to anchor the thought process by paraphrasing the original prompt in the solver’s own words. They explicitly name the issue to be resolved—often prefaced by conversational markers like “Okay, so I have this problem…” or “I’m trying to figure out…”—but do not yet supply analysis, evidence, or a solution strategy. Their cognitive role is to ensure clarity about what question is being answered before any reasoning steps, plans, or hypotheses are introduced.
Declarative Knowledge & Intermediate-Result Assertions

These utterances supply concrete premises that the rest of the chain of thought will build on. They either recall settled domain facts (definitions, formulas, standard values) or report the immediate outcome of a straightforward sub-calculation or balancing step. Expressed as matter-of-fact statements (“The sulfate ion has a charge of –2.” “Moles of H₂: 0.05 × 3 = 0.15 mol.”), they neither speculate nor direct future actions; their sole function is to place reliable, ready-to-use information into the reasoning workspace.
Problem-Decomposition Cue

These meta-cognitive statements announce the reasoner’s intention to dissect the task and proceed methodically, but do not yet perform any substantive analysis. They orient the upcoming reasoning by signalling a step-by-step breakdown, often using self-directed phrases like “let me break this down,” “I’ll think through it step by step,” “where do I start,” or “first, I should restate the problem.”
Metacognitive Self-Check & Error-Flagging

These utterances interrupt the flow of reasoning to express doubt about the immediately preceding line of thought, signal a possible mistake, or call for a quick re-examination before proceeding. Typical cues include hesitations (“wait,” “hold on,” “hmm”), direct error signals (“that’s not right,” “maybe I made a mistake”), and skeptical questions (“is that right?”). They do not present new hypotheses or lay out future steps; their sole function is to monitor, question, and, if needed, correct the current reasoning path.
Speculative Hypothesis / Possibility Generation

These sentences enlarge the solution space by positing tentative explanations, consequences, or courses of action. Characterized by modal verbs and hedging terms (“might,” “could,” “maybe,” “perhaps”), they present alternative causes, effects, or strategies without committing to any single one, thereby supplying options the subsequent reasoning can test or refine.
Background‐Knowledge Recall & Conceptual Clarification

These sentences surface pre-existing domain knowledge—definitions, formulas, standard procedures, and accepted theoretical relationships—to ground the ongoing analysis. They explain what a term means, restate a known result, or outline how a canonical method works (e.g., giving the Durbin-Watson formula, noting that panel data mix cross-sectional and time-series aspects, or reminding that GARCH(1,1) models volatility clustering). They are informational rather than speculative or directive: they neither propose new hypotheses nor announce future steps, but instead supply the conceptual scaffolding on which later reasoning operates.
Principle/Concept Recall and Articulation

These sentences retrieve and articulate established domain knowledge—definitions, laws, formulas, and standard cause-effect relationships—and sometimes draw the immediate textbook implication of that knowledge. Their purpose is to supply the reasoning trace with authoritative economic principles that later steps can apply, rather than to speculate, admit uncertainty, or plan actions. Typical signals include phrases like “I recall that…,” “One key concept is…,” or straightforward statements of laws (e.g., “In a perfectly competitive market, price equals the minimum ATC”) and direct deductions that flow mechanically from those principles (e.g., “So, the equilibrium quantity supplied would increase, and the equilibrium price would also increase”).
Rule Recall / Doctrine Articulation

These utterances retrieve and state the governing principle, definition, or black-letter rule that the reasoner will later apply to the case. They often begin with cues such as “I recall that…,” “Impossibility is…,” or “Constructive eviction requires…,” and supply concise statements of law or domain knowledge (“A general warranty deed warrants against all defects,” “The remainder is fixed once the life estate is created”). By explicitly laying out the underlying doctrine, they equip the reasoning chain with the normative benchmark against which the specific facts can be tested.
Background‐Knowledge Recall & Conceptual Clarification

These sentences retrieve and articulate previously learned information—definitions, distinctions, summaries of thinkers’ positions, typical objections, or illustrative examples—in order to clarify the concepts that the later argument will rely on. The speaker is not advancing a new hypothesis or announcing a next step; rather, they are laying conceptual groundwork by explaining what “natural law” means, what utilitarianism entails, why “poisoning the well” is a fallacy, how Rawls frames fairness, etc. Typical cues include “as I recall,” “means that,” “in summary,” “he argued that,” or comparisons like “X focuses on…, whereas Y emphasizes…,” all aimed at ensuring the key ideas and terminology are correctly understood before further reasoning proceeds.
Concept/Term Clarification

These sentences pause the reasoning to explicitly define, paraphrase, or contrast technical terms and theoretical constructs so that subsequent argumentation rests on a shared understanding of what each label means. Typical cues include copular constructions (“X means…,” “X is when…”), contrastive frames (“whereas,” “while”), parenthetic glosses, or brief textbook-style summaries of key ideas. Examples: defining reinforcement schedules, explaining “explicit vs. incidental memory,” stating the levels of Schein’s model, or contrasting behaviorism with social learning theory.
Stepwise Plan Declaration

These sentences explicitly announce the next procedural move in a multi-step solution. They frame the reasoning as an ordered sequence (“First…,” “Next…,” “Then…,” “Finally…”) or with forward-looking infinitives (“To find…,” “I need to determine…”), thereby decomposing the overall task into manageable sub-goals before (and sometimes while) executing them. The key signal is that the sentence’s primary purpose is to declare or label the upcoming operation, not to justify a hypothesis or express uncertainty.
Background Knowledge Recall

These sentences retrieve and state factual information, definitions, or conceptual relationships already stored in memory so that the subsequent reasoning can build on them. They often begin with metacognitive cues like “I remember,” “I know,” “I think,” or “I’ve heard,” and then supply a concrete fact or explanation (e.g., “The reticular formation is part of the brainstem,” “Progesterone is made by the corpus luteum and helps thicken the uterine lining”). They are not proposing new hypotheses or expressing uncertainty; rather, they supply supporting domain knowledge that anchors the argument or analysis.
Prior-Knowledge Recall

These utterances explicitly summon background information—definitions, formulas, theories, or factual tidbits—that the reasoner already “remembers” and expects to use in the ensuing analysis. They typically begin with cues such as “I remember that…,” “Let me recall…,” “First, I should recall/remember…,” or “I know that…,” and function to load previously learned material into working memory before new reasoning steps are attempted.
Recall/Statement of Known Principles or Formulas

These sentences explicitly bring a previously learned law, definition, standard equation, or canonical relationship into the workspace so it can be applied to the current problem. They typically begin with cues like “I remember that…,” “First, I recognize that…,” or directly state “Power is …,” “The cutoff frequency is …,” etc. Their purpose is not to speculate or plan but to supply authoritative domain knowledge (e.g., Ohm’s law, P = V²/R, reflection-coefficient definitions) that subsequent computational steps will use.
Sanity-Check / Result-Validation Statements

These utterances give an immediate, informal verdict on whether a just-derived sub-result, calculation, or logical step appears plausible, consistent, or erroneous. They function as the reasoner’s on-the-fly quality control—either affirming (“that seems right,” “yep, that checks out”) or flagging doubt (“wait, that seems too high,” “that can’t be right”)—before the reasoning proceeds.

0.title: Problem-Given Restatement / Fact Extraction
0.description: These sentences simply pull information straight from the prompt—repeating the question, listing numerical values, naming variables, or rephrasing what must be found. They function to get all the “givens” onto the workspace before any real analysis begins. Typical cues include phrases like “The problem says…,” “The question is asking…,” “First, the problem gives…,” or “The goal is…,” followed by verbatim data or task statements rather than interpretation or calculation.
examples: It says that a sample of 4.50 grams of methane occupies 12.7 dm³ at 310 K. I need to calculate the work done when the gas expands isothermally against a constant external pressure of 200 Torr until its volume has increased by 3.3 dm³

Part (a) says: What force will be required to move a short-circuited conductor across a magnetic field of 5,000 gauss if the conductor is 100 centimeters long, moves at a uniform speed of 100 centimeters per second, and the circuit has a resistance of 0.04 ohm

1.title: Intermediate Deductive Inference
1.description: These sentences articulate conclusions or quantitative relationships that follow directly from earlier premises, definitions, or standard formulas. They do not merely cite uncertainty or outline a plan; instead, they carry the reasoning forward by applying known laws (“since F = ma…”, “λ = v/f so the wavelength changes”) or by syllogistic logic (“so the lever arm is zero”, “therefore power is inversely proportional to n − 1”). Functionally, they serve as stepping-stone results—explicitly stating what has just been deduced so that later steps can build on these established intermediate facts.
examples: The net force is equal to mass times acceleration, so F_net = m*a. Here, the net force is the sum of the gravitational force and the resistive force
Since the electron is released from rest, I guess I can use Newton's second law here, which is F = ma, where m is the mass and a is the acceleration
So, if I denote the tension as T, then according to Newton's second law, the net force on the elevator should be equal to its mass times the acceleration

So, for James, the net force is T - m_j * g, but wait, actually, the tension is pulling him toward Ramon, so the force on James is T, and the force on Ramon is also T. But since they're moving toward each other, the direction of the tension is opposite to their motion

Now, the particle starts with an initial velocity V, and due to the electric force, it accelerates, moving a distance d. I think I can use the kinematic equation to relate the initial velocity, acceleration, and distance

So, the key here is that the retarding force is constant, so the acceleration of the block (and the bullet) is constant because \( F = ma \), so if \( F \) is constant and \( m \) is constant, then \( a \) is constant

So, the net force on the lighter person is the applied force F minus the normal force N. But since the ice is frictionless, the normal force is equal to the weight of the lighter person, which is mg, where m is 50 kg and g is acceleration due to gravity
There's no friction, so the only horizontal force is T. So the net force on the physics book is T, and that equals mass times acceleration
But let me also recall that in projectile motion, the net force is equal to the derivative of momentum, which is the acceleration

So, for James, the tension T is the only horizontal force acting on him, so F_net = T - m_j * g. Similarly, for Ramon, F_net = T - m_r * g. But actually, since they're on a frozen pond, friction is negligible, so the only horizontal forces are the tension forces
So the net force on the math book is mg - T, and that equals mass times acceleration
The force on the electron is F = qE, and since it's moving, the net force is F = ma
So, if I can model the forces acting on the chain, I can set up an equation where the net force equals zero because there's no acceleration
Since friction is the only force, the acceleration is constant and opposite to the direction of motion
If the chain is moving with constant velocity, the net force is zero, so the applied force P must equal the weight of the chain minus the normal force

2.title: Explicit Uncertainty & Tentative Estimation
2.description: These sentences openly signal that the reasoner lacks precise knowledge, is recalling information only approximately, or must consult outside sources before firming up a claim. Typical linguistic markers include “I’m not sure,” “maybe,” “I think,” “I recall,” “it might be,” and “I should check.” The function is to flag epistemic limits, supply rough provisional numbers or impressions, and prompt follow-up verification rather than to advance a definite hypothesis or conclusion.
examples: I should check the latest data from reliable sources
I should check if there's any reliable source that provides this statistic
I should probably look up the most recent data available, which would be around 2017
Alternatively, the CDC in the U.S. also tracks obesity rates, but I'm not sure if it's specific to 2016 or more recent
I should check if there are any recent studies because the numbers might have changed
The World Bank might have the most recent data, so I can check that
I think the WHO releases reports periodically, so maybe the 2016 report is available online
I wonder if there's a specific report or publication from 2015 that has this data
I wonder if there are any specific studies or reports from 2019 that provide more precise numbers
I think the WHO has some data on this
Maybe I can look up some reports or data they've published
I should check if there are any reputable sources that have this information
I should also check if there are any recent studies that have updated these numbers
I wonder if there are any recent studies or data that have updated these numbers
I should look for the most recent and reliable data to confirm this

3.title: Rule/Criteria Recall
3.description: These utterances retrieve and articulate established doctrinal rules, statutory elements, or standard tests that must be applied to the facts. The speaker is essentially “quoting from the rulebook,” listing the definitional ingredients of crimes, torts, or defenses (“Negligence requires duty, breach, causation, and damages,” “Voluntary manslaughter involves heat of passion,” “For self-defense the defendant must reasonably fear imminent harm”). They convey settled knowledge rather than speculation, uncertainty, or procedural planning, and serve to anchor later analysis in the correct governing standards.
examples: Alternatively, if the defendant didn't intend to cause harm but his actions were so negligent that they created a risk, then reckless endangerment could be the charge
In some jurisdictions, if the defendant's actions unreasonably risk causing harm, it can be considered reckless endangerment
Another angle is whether the defendant's actions were so reckless that they constitute criminal negligence
However, if the defendant's actions were so dangerous that they created a high risk of harm, it could be criminal negligence
In some cases, if the defendant didn't intend to cause the fire but was grossly negligent in leaving the stove on, that could be enough for a charge
The defendant might argue that he didn't intend to harm anyone, but that doesn't negate the fact that his reckless driving was a cause of the injury
I also recall that sometimes, even if there's no intent to harm, if the natural consequences of an action are foreseeable, it can still lead to liability

However, some jurisdictions might consider the act of leaving the stove on as a reckless act, which could be sufficient for arson, even if it's not intentional

4.title: Alternative-Hypothesis Generation (Differential Building)
4.description: These utterances introduce or weigh possible explanations, diagnoses, or interventions that might account for the data at hand. Characterised by modals and hedging phrases (“could be,” “might,” “maybe,” “alternatively,” “I should also consider”), they list or compare candidate conditions, mechanisms, or next steps, often adding quick evidence for or against each. Their cognitive role is to expand the search space by constructing a differential set of competing hypotheses that later reasoning will confirm, refine, or discard.
examples: I should also consider other possibilities, like infective endocarditis, but her murmur has been there since early adulthood, and there's no mention of fever or other signs of infection

I should also consider other possibilities, like a heart murmur from a different cause, but given the family history and the presence of a midsystolic click, connective tissue disorders seem more likely

Also, aortic dissection would present with more acute symptoms, maybe even syncope or shock, but he's presenting with sweating and shortness of breath, which could be due to tachycardia or anxiety, but the physical exam points more towards a structural issue
The weight loss and dry eyes/mouth make me think of possible neurogenerative conditions, but the smoking history and chest findings point towards a possible neurological issue related to his lungs
Alternatively, the chest pain could be due to a panic attack, but given the physical signs, that's less likely
Rhonchi are heard in the left lower lobe, so he's got pneumonia, but that's probably not directly related to the skin issue
Meningitis is another consideration because it can cause fever and nuchal rigidity, but she doesn't mention any neurological symptoms or a stiff neck, so that's less likely
But she's not feverish, and her vital signs are normal, so maybe it's not an abscess

5.title: Question Parsing & Option-Filtering
5.description: These sentences explicitly analyze the exam-style prompt itself—restating what the question asks, recalling or hypothesizing the given choices, and articulating the rule for picking the correct (or incorrect/exception) option. The reasoner is not yet supplying domain facts but setting the decision frame: “the question is asking which…,” “the options are…,” “I need to decide which statement is false,” “if one option says…, that would be wrong.” By clarifying scope, surfacing missing choices, and announcing provisional eliminations, they narrow the candidate answers before substantive justification begins.
examples: Wait, the user didn't provide options, but the original question is asking which is NOT one of the factors
The user didn't provide the options, but the question is asking which isn't a component of market orientation

But the question is phrased as "which of the following occurs," implying that there might be options, but since the user didn't provide them, I need to figure out the correct answer based on my understanding
Wait, the user's question is asking which is NOT a property, so I need to pick the incorrect one
Wait, the user's question is asking which is not one of those circumstances
Wait, but the user didn't provide the options, so I need to think about what the question is asking
But the user didn't provide options, so I need to think about what the possible answer might be

Now, the user mentioned that the options are not provided, but in a typical question like this, the options would include various governance-related terms, and one of them wouldn't fit as an underlying principle
Wait, the user's initial question was about which is NOT a defining feature
Wait, the question is asking which of the following is true, but the options aren't provided
Looking back, the user mentioned that the options aren't provided, but I think the question is asking for the one that's not a recognized complication
But the question is asking for which of the following initiatives, so I need to see what options are given
The options are likely B, C, or D. But the question is phrased as "which of the following statements would supply-side economists disagree with," implying one correct answer
Wait, but the user mentioned that the options aren't listed here, so maybe I should consider that the answer is something else
Wait, the question isn't giving me the options, but I'm supposed to figure out which part is excluded

6.title: Intermediate Causal-Inference / Mechanism Elaboration
6.description: These sentences take a fact, formula, or premise that has just been stated and immediately work out what follows from it, laying out the causal or quantitative implications that move the argument forward. Marked by cue words such as “so,” “that means,” “if … then,” “therefore,” or modal verbs (“would,” “could,” “might”), they apply domain rules to derive an intermediate result, explain a mechanism, or predict a downstream effect (e.g., “so the bank can lend more,” “higher interest rates reduce investment,” “this could worsen the trade deficit”). The function is to stitch facts into a logical chain that bridges raw data and the eventual conclusion.
examples: So, if you increase the money supply, it can help stimulate the economy by making credit cheaper and encouraging spending
If the central bank tightens monetary policy, interest rates go up, which can reduce investment and consumption, leading to a decrease in real GDP
If the money supply increases, people have more money, which might increase their spending, thus increasing aggregate demand
A tax cut increases disposable income, which can lead to higher demand for goods and services

7.title: Contextual Knowledge Recall & Elaboration
7.description: These sentences inject remembered or generally‐known facts, descriptions, or illustrative examples into the discussion so the reasoner has raw material to work with. Typically framed in a first-person or hedged style (“I remember…,” “I think…,” “Maybe…,” “Alternatively…”), they restate background history, definitions, timelines, or comparative details without yet committing to a conclusion or outlining a next step. Their function is to stock the workspace with potentially relevant information that subsequent reasoning can test, refine, or discard.
examples: I think domestication of crops like rice and millet in China is generally attributed to earlier cultures, but the Yangshao sites show evidence of their use, which suggests they were already domesticated when the Yangshao culture emerged

8.title: Intermediate Quantitative Calculation
8.description: These sentences perform the concrete mathematics inside the broader argument. They set up formulas, define or label variables, plug specific numbers into those formulas, carry out arithmetic, and state the resulting interim figures. Typical signals include verbs like “calculate,” “compute,” “determine,” or phrases such as “so the present value is…,” “where r is…,” “plugging in the numbers,” or “therefore the amount equals….” They supply the numerical scaffolding that later reasoning steps will reference or build upon.

9.title: Explicit Intermediate Calculation
9.description: These sentences carry out and state the results of low-level arithmetic or algebraic operations—multiplications, divisions, exponentiation, unit conversions, rounding, or quick magnitude checks—that advance the solution of a larger quantitative problem. They neither introduce new hypotheses nor reflect on uncertainty; their sole purpose is to convert given numbers or symbolic expressions into the next numeric value needed for the overall argument. Typical cues include verbs like “so,” “then,” “first,” or “let me compute,” followed by concrete numeric manipulation and an immediate stated result or approximation.

10.title: Unit-Conversion & Dimensional-Consistency Check

11.title: Factor Enumeration / Perspective Expansion
11.description: These statements deliberately broaden the scope of inquiry by listing further variables, angles, examples, exceptions, or contextual details that might matter. They function as self-reminders to keep the reasoning comprehensive rather than drawing conclusions, often introduced with phrases like “I should also consider…,” “Another point is…,” “Another angle…,” or “I also wonder….”
examples: I should also think about historical examples
I should also think about examples

13.title: Intermediate Derivation / Computation Reporting
13.description: These sentences state the immediate outcome of a just-performed algebraic, numeric, or logical operation, locking in a partial result before the reasoning proceeds. They present definitive conclusions of sub-calculations (“So, w = 0”, “det(A) = 1”, “15*10x = 150x”), give simplified expressions or evaluated probabilities, or note a corrected derivation (“Wait, no, each double bond has one sigma and one pi”). Typically introduced by cues like “so,” “that means,” “which gives,” they neither propose new hypotheses nor lay out future steps but simply record the concrete result of a computation or local inference.

14.title: Explicit Uncertainty Acknowledgment
14.description: These utterances serve a metacognitive role: the reasoner overtly flags doubt, gaps in knowledge, or possible mistakes in the ongoing line of thought. They do not advance a new hypothesis or plan; instead they mark the current claim or recollection as tentative and signal that verification or clarification is still needed. Typical linguistic cues include “I’m not sure…,” “I might be mixing this up…,” “I’m a bit confused…,” “I don’t think that’s right,” or “I’m not 100 % certain.”

28.title: Metacognitive Self-Check & Error-Flagging
28.description: These utterances interrupt the flow of reasoning to express doubt about the immediately preceding line of thought, signal a possible mistake, or call for a quick re-examination before proceeding. Typical cues include hesitations (“wait,” “hold on,” “hmm”), direct error signals (“that’s not right,” “maybe I made a mistake”), and skeptical questions (“is that right?”). They do not present new hypotheses or lay out future steps; their sole function is to monitor, question, and, if needed, correct the current reasoning path.

29.title: Speculative Hypothesis / Possibility Generation

31.title: Principle/Concept Recall and Articulation
31.description: These sentences retrieve and articulate established domain knowledge—definitions, laws, formulas, and standard cause-effect relationships—and sometimes draw the immediate textbook implication of that knowledge. 32.title: Rule Recall / Doctrine Articulation

36.title: Background Knowledge Recall
36.description: These sentences retrieve and state factual information, definitions, or conceptual relationships already stored in memory so that the subsequent reasoning can build on them. 37.title: Prior-Knowledge Recall

39.title: Sanity-Check / Result-Validation Statements
39.description: These utterances give an immediate, informal verdict on whether a just-derived sub-result, calculation, or logical step appears plausible, consistent, or erroneous. They function as the reasoner’s on-the-fly quality control—either affirming (“that seems right,” “yep, that checks out”) or flagging doubt (“wait, that seems too high,” “that can’t be right”)—before the reasoning proceeds.
